name: Rep. Andy Levin
tweet_text: Maintaining yoga practice across decades hasn’t been a walk in the park, & I have gone through long fallow periods of hardly practicing at all. Life in Congress is so stressful & crazy. So I’ve made a new commitment. I’m going to do at least 1 asana every day I’m in my DC office.

name: Rep. Andy Levin
tweet_text: My back became stronger and more flexible than it had ever been in my life, and my long history of back problems became a terrain of turning a weakness into an area of growth. Of course, along the way, the rest of my body benefited, too.

name: Rep. Andy Levin
tweet_text: That’s when my yoga life started. Moving quickly through poses wasn’t for me, my back was too unstable. I discovered Iyengar yoga, a practice of deep & rigorous exploration of yoga asanas (poses) w/ highly trained teachers. I began attending weekly classes and practicing at home.

name: Rep. Andy Levin
tweet_text: After a quest that led through many practitioners that culminated in a team of a functional medicine doctor, acupuncture, physical therapist and massage therapist. The doctor made me get off the road and after intensive treatment my back was stabilized.

name: Rep. Andy Levin
tweet_text: With Ben’s arrival, we had three kids under five in the house, and I was working a chaotic national travel kind of job for the @AFLCIO. I started to experience not only back pain, but sciatica down my left leg and across my foot.

name: Rep. Andy Levin
tweet_text: Whether worshipping in their synagogues, frequenting their local Jewish Community Centers, attending Jewish schools or just walking down the street, Jews face growing threats and hostility.

name: Rep. Andy Levin
tweet_text: .@ADL’s latest report reveals what we all know to be true: the scourge of antisemitism continues to threaten Jews across the US.

name: Rep. Andy Levin
tweet_text: Further, attacks against Jewish institutions increased 61%, incidents at K-12 schools increased 106%, and incidents on college campuses increased 21%. Michiganders experienced more than double the number of antisemitic incidents in 2021 compared to 2020.

name: Rep. Andy Levin
tweet_text: Alarmingly, @ADL's audit found that antisemitic incidents  increased across all categories—assault, harassment and vandalism.

name: Rep. Andy Levin
tweet_text: I urge my colleagues to reconcile with the findings in this report and recommit to calling out antisemitism in all its forms–loudly and consistently. We must continue building coalitions to fight antisemitism and battle all forms of hate, ignorance and bigotry. https://t.co/mFhAjkG4hn

name: Rep. Andy Levin
tweet_text: Congress hasn’t passed pro-worker labor law reform for private sector workers since the Wagner Act in 1935. That’s 86 years! It’s time to #PassThePROAct.

name: Rep. Andy Levin
tweet_text: Just in the last two years, we’ve lived and worked through a housing crisis, climate emergencies, and the COVID-19 pandemic. Millions of workers remain underpaid and overworked.

name: Rep. Andy Levin
tweet_text: Overworked and underpaid workers, economic recession, wage inequality, and strikes across the country–sound familiar? We are now in another historic moment ripe with possibility. Americans have suffered decades of growing inequality with stagnant wages and rising costs.

name: Rep. Andy Levin
tweet_text: The textile workers strike involved 400,000 workers up and down the East Coast. Thousands of workers joined in solidarity and found their power.

name: Rep. Andy Levin
tweet_text: These strikes included workplace walkouts; factory takeovers; and city-wide general strikes. The 1934 Longshoremen's Strike lasted 83 days, including a city-wide San Francisco general strike.

name: Rep. Andy Levin
tweet_text: Let’s talk about labor law in history: a thread🧵. The Wagner Act followed years of militant worker organizing. In 1933, the nation saw the start of a massive strike wave fueled by worker discontent amidst the Great Depression and desire for stronger union protections.

name: Rep. Andy Levin
tweet_text: Did I miss anything @Amazon?

name: Rep. Andy Levin
tweet_text:
More (remember, Amazon calls these workers “independent”):

❌Restrictions for terminating the business relationship during the busy season
❌Mandatory at-will employment so workers can be fired any time for no reason
❌Limited press statements unless Amazon gives permission.

name: Rep. Andy Levin
tweet_text:
Surely this must be the end of the list (it’s not):

❌Mandatory non-disclosure agreements
❌In-vehicle surveillance cameras
❌Cancellation fees
❌Mandatory arbitration for contractors and their workers

name: Rep. Andy Levin
tweet_text:
And more after that:

❌Access to and unlimited use of data including location, speed, and GPS tracking, even after the business relationship ends
❌Indemnification of Amazon in serious cases where someone is hurt or dies
❌Control over litigation strategy if a lawsuit arises

name: Rep. Andy Levin
tweet_text:
And a few more:

❌Workers’ social media posts  
❌Use Amazon-approved training
❌Use of Amazon’s delivery app
❌Mandatory drug tests for workers whenever Amazon wants
❌Physical access to their premises

name: Rep. Andy Levin
tweet_text:
A not-so-brief list of ways Amazon controls supposedly “independent” contractors and their workers, per @josheidelson:

❌Workers’ personal grooming
❌Workers’ usage of perfume/cologne
❌Workers’ dental hygiene
❌Workers’ fingernails and hair

name: Rep. Andy Levin
tweet_text: This is exactly what we mean when we talk about worker misclassification. Drivers are “independent” except that Amazon controls basically every aspect of how they operate and can unilaterally change any of these working conditions on a whim. All while avoiding federal law. https://t.co/9RWGO7yowK

tweet_text: My amdt will allow Violence Against Women Act funding to be used to implement vertical prosecution systems. I want every survivor’s case to get the attention and care it deserves and, most importantly, I want every survivor to feel like they are truly heard and represented. 7/

name: Rep. Andy Levin
tweet_text: As you can imagine, one of the big reasons vertical prosecution doesn’t happen as much as it should is the cost. District attorneys’ offices do not always have the resources to hire more attorneys to handle cases. 6/

name: Rep. Andy Levin
tweet_text:
According to the National Sexual Violence Resource Center, ‘vertical prosecution has shown to improve conviction rates, reduce victim trauma, and provide more consistent, appropriate sentencing.’ 5/

https://t.co/d6V01uISIr

name: Rep. Andy Levin
tweet_text: She asked that I encourage what’s called ‘vertical prosecution,’ a plan for prosecuting cases in which one prosecuting attorney remains the primary individual responsible for the case, as well as the primary contact for victim witnesses from complaint through sentencing. 4/

name: Rep. Andy Levin
tweet_text: This is a process that’s harrowing enough on its own. To have to relive what happened over and over in order to get a new attorney up to speed—to not feel like you have a relationship with that person—it’s just unthinkable to me. 3/

name: Rep. Andy Levin
tweet_text: She shared that, over the course of her legal proceedings, she’d had five different prosecutors on her case. And, not surprisingly, she felt like none of them were really representing her. 2/

name: Rep. Andy Levin
tweet_text:
I’m feeling especially emotional about the vote on the Violence Against Women Act reauthorization today because I was able to get an amendment included in this bill that was inspired by a conversation I had with a constituent last year. 

She had survived a sexual assault. 

1/
